item.title: China Pulls Back From One Disputed Border, Makes New Claims on Another
item.description: China and India began pulling back troops from the site of a deadly border clash, as Beijing opened a new front in the region’s territorial disputes with a new claim in nearby Bhutan.

item.title: What Restaurants Need to Reopen: A Flatter Infection Curve and Fresh Air
item.description: Europe’s reopened bistros, pizzerias and cafes are bustling with clientele but unlike those in America's Sunbelt have had no major outbreaks. The difference stems from Europe’s success in flattening its infection curve before reopening and less reliance on air conditioning.

item.title: As Coronavirus Surges in U.S., Some Countries Have Just About Halted It
item.description: Containing the pandemic has allowed a handful of countries to reopen their economies sooner and with greater confidence than harder-hit U.S. states or the U.K.

item.title: China Detains One of Xi Jinping's Most Prominent Critics
item.description: Xu Zhangrun, a law professor at Beijing’s Tsinghua University, is known as one of the few prominent voices in China still willing to openly criticize the president’s leadership.

item.title: How Kremlin's View of U.S.'s War in Afghanistan Has Shifted
item.description: Analysis: For years, the U.S. and Russia shared a goal of deposing the Taliban government. But that common purpose has crumbled amid mutual suspicion.

item.title: As Ethiopia Prepares to Fill Nile Dam, Egypt Appeals for International Help
item.description: Egypt is attempting to raise international pressure on Ethiopia to strike a deal on the use of water from the Nile, which sustains life for tens of millions of people, as Addis Ababa prepares to begin filling a massive hydroelectric dam on a branch of the river this month.
